data.text: Contents
Introduction

To define the preoperative fasting protocol for adult and paediatric patients undergoing procedures under general anaesthesia, regional anaesthesia and sedation i.e. monitored anaesthesia care based on current recommendations.

Preoperative fasting is intended to reduce the risk of pulmonary aspiration of gastric contents the complications of which are aspiration pneumonia, respiratory disability and related morbidity and mortality.
Scope
This document applies to all adult and paediatric patients undergoing monitored anaesthesia care in the Trust.
These guidelines are based on the most recent recommendations of the American Society of Anaesthesiologists guideline and the European Society of Anaesthesiology guideline.
Definitions
Role and responsibilities within the Trust
Chief Executive:

The Chief Executive as the Accounting Officer has overall responsibility for the quality and safety of services provided by the Trust. In this respect, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document is available. He/she will delegate the full implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director.
Medical Director:

The Medical Director is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that the infrastructure required to support the delivery and implementation of this document to a relevant Executive Director. In addition, he/she is responsible for ensuring that the monitoring and audit of this document is undertaken and reported in the appropriate forum as indicated in the document.
Director of Nursing:

The Director of Nursing is responsible for ensuring that the necessary systems, processes, training and competency assessment (where appropriate) are available to ensure that all non-medical staff (nurses, midwives and allied health professionals) are able to comply with the contents of this document.
Director of Operations:
The Director of Operations is responsible for ensuring that there are systems and processes in place to communicate and implement this document in the clinical areas.
Divisional Clinical Directors:

The Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that systems and processes are in place throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate. In addition, the Divisional Clinical Directors are responsible for ensuring that all medical and dental staff complies with the contents of the document.
Divisional General Managers

The Divisional General Managers are responsible for implementing the systems and processes required throughout the Divisions to ensure that this document is disseminated appropriately and that monitoring of compliance is undertaken, with remedial action implemented as appropriate.
Heads of Nursing and Quality (HoNQ):
The HoNQs are responsible for ensuring that the policy is disseminated throughout the Division and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken, with the resources provided to support this.
Clinical Leads / Service Unit Managers(SUM's):

Clinical Service Unit Clinical Leads and Unit Managers are responsible for implementing this document in the Clinical Service Unit and for monitoring the impact on the service and reporting compliance with the document. They are accountable to the Divisional Clinical Director and General Manager in this respect.
Divisional Governance Leads

Divisional Governance Leads are responsible for reporting to HoNQ and Clinical Directors any diversion from this policy and that the required monitoring and audits are undertaken to provide assurance of compliance with this policy.
Head of Therapies:

The Head of Therapies (HoT) is responsible for ensuring that this document is fully implemented at department level. This will include making sure all relevant and necessary training is given and received, that the introduction of the document is monitored and therefore assessing the impact this is having on service delivery. In addition, the HoT is responsible for ensuring that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken within the Therapy CSU and reported through the relevant governance system.
Supervisors of Midwives:

The SoM is responsible for ensuring that the policy is complied with and disseminated to all midwifery staff and that the required monitoring and audit are undertaken to ensure compliance. They are accountable to the LSMO for all elements of midwifery professional performance.
Lead Nurses:

Lead Nurses are responsible for ensuring that all nursing staff (including Nurse Specialists, Practitioners/Advisors) within the Clinical Service Unit complies with the contents of this document and for taking action when this is not the case. The Lead Nurse will make sure that all necessary training is provided.
Medical Staff

The Consultant holds ultimate responsibility for ensuring that all members of the medical team are compliant with this document. Where there are concerns with complying with the contents of this document, these should be discussed with the Clinical Director and documented in the patient's healthcare records any deviation from this policy.
Matrons

Matrons are responsible for ensuring that this policy has been disseminated and gain assurance of compliance with these guidelines. Where there are inconsistencies with the policy, will assist with ward Senior Sisters undertaking a Root Cause Analysis and disseminated to appropriate personnel.
Senior Sisters

The Senior Sister/nurse in charge is accountable for the safe care and management of patient on the ward. They are therefore responsible for ensuring that all staff are familiar with this document and where there is evidence of non-compliance will undertake a Root Cause Analysis with the support of the Matron and disseminate to the appropriate personnel.
All Registered Nurses

All Registered nurses must ensure they have read and understood the policy and incorporate the guidance into their clinical practice. All Registered Nurses are responsible for their education and have a responsibility to attend relevant training as appropriate to their individual role in line with NMC Code of Conduct.
All staff including Patient Services Assistant/Ward Hostess/Housekeeper

All staff will seek and adhere to the guidance and support from the Registered Nurses of care provision for the patient and ensure they are aware of notification of dietary and oral intake requirements or NBM and fasting orders accordingly. Staff must alert the Registered Nurse if there are any concerns.
Fasting guidelines
Adults
Hours before anaesthesia for solid food or enteral feed.
2 hours before anaesthesia for clear fluid.
Infants (age less than 1 year)
6 hours before anaesthesia for infant formula, cow's milk, solids or enteral feed.
4 hours before anaesthesia for breast milk.
2 hours before anaesthesia for clear fluids.
Children (age between 1 and 16 years)
6 hours before anaesthesia for formula, cow's milk, solids or enteral feed.
4 hours before anaesthesia for breast milk.
Wizard Ward: 1 hour before anaesthesia for clear fluids (see attached appendix 1 guideline.)

Phoenix Ward: On Phoenix ward the 3 groups of children are: Elective Cleft surgery and Orthopaedic surgery– they have standard admission times as per Wizard Ward and can have measured drink on admission (i.e. at 7.30 or 11.30/ 12.00) (refer to appendix 1 guideline). Max fax and Plastic trauma children – nurses will liaise with anaesthetist but can have measured drink up to 1 hour before surgery (refer to appendix 1 guideline)
Emergency Orthopaedic and general surgery - no change in fluid fasting advice (i.e. 2 hours). Some of these children may be nil by mouth.

Children's Burn Ward , anaesthetist to liaise with nursing staff preferably night before about fluid fasting times, those with normal gastric emptying can have measured drink up to 1 hour before surgery (refer to appendix 1 guideline).
Obstetric Patients
As for adults for elective procedures.
Clear fluids should be encouraged in labour.
Plastic Surgery Hand Trauma Patients and Elective Hand Patients
For operations planned as regional anaesthesia only.
Clear fluids allowed up until patient leaves ward for theatre.

For the purposes of these guidelines clear fluids constitutes fluid through which print can be read and does not contain alcohol or milk. It includes black tea and coffee, pulp free fruit juices, fizzy/carbonated drinks and carbohydrate-rich drinks.
Chewing gum and boiled sweets are allowed up to 2 hours before anaesthesia. After this point they should be removed to prevent oral retention on induction of anaesthesia.
However, patients should not be postponed or delayed solely because they have been chewing gum or sucking boiled sweets immediately prior to the induction of anaesthesia
Infants and children are defined as per the Practice guidelines for preoperative fasting of the American Society of Anaesthesiologists Committee 2017.

The anaesthetist has final say for the fasting policy in each individual patient in their care and may request alternative fasting times for particular patients or procedures. These should be clearly documented in the medical notes.
In the case of non-elective procedures where the patient is not fully fasted the risk of aspiration must be balanced against the urgency and the risks of the procedure.
Fasting requirements in Adults and Children
Adults and children should be encouraged to drink clear fluids (including water, pulp-free juice, tea or coffee without milk) up to two hours before elective surgery (including caesarean section).
Solid foods should be prohibited for six hours before elective surgery in both adults and children. For endoscopy patients, please see separate advice.

Specialist Carbohydrate-rich drinks (not including fizzy drinks) should be encouraged up to 2 hours prior to surgery to improve post-operative recovery rates (ERAS & European Society for Anaesthesiology 2011 guidelines). Drinking carbohydrate-rich fluids before elective surgery reduces the stress response to surgery, and improves subjective well-being, reduces thirst and hunger and reduces post-operative insulin resistance therefore aiding recovery.
Patients with obesity, gastro-oesophageal reflux, diabetics and pregnant women not in labour can safely follow these guidelines.
Patients should not have their operation cancelled or delayed as a result of chewing gum, sucking a boiled sweet or smoking immediately prior to induction of anaesthesia.
Fasting in infants

Infants should be fed before elective surgery. Breast milk is safe up to four hours and other milks up to six hours prior to surgery. Thereafter, clear fluids may be given up to two hours prior to surgery as in adults and children.
Fasting in obstetric patients

Follow Trust guidelines - Women should be allowed clear fluids (as defined above) as they desire in labour and should be advised that these are preferably isotonic drinks. These drinks are similar in concentrations of sugars and salt as the human body. There are many brands on the market such as Lucozade non- carbonated Sport drinks. Alternatively one part fresh orange juice and one part water with a pinch of salt to prevent dehydration and fatigue during labour.
A light diet may be eaten in established labour unless they have received opioids or develop risk factors that make a general anaesthetic more likely (NICE 2007).
Elective caesarean section patients should be two hours fasting from clear fluids and abstain from food for six hours prior to planned section.
A carbohydrate loaded drink to be given 2 hours prior to the section to prevent dehydration, an optimum metabolic state and patient comfort and recovery.
Non-elective caesarean patients will be carried out as an emergency and therefore will not be fasting. See Trust Guidelines for Caesarean Sections.
Fasting for Diabetic Patients

The needs of all patients with diabetes must be identified at pre-assessment clinic to ensure that patients receive correct information regarding their diabetic medication prior to their admission. Care and advice will be provided to patients with diabetes that promotes optimal glycaemic control. The clinical team must ensure that diabetic patients are not scheduled late on the operating/procedures list to avoid prolonged periods of fasting and metabolic consequences and surgical stress. The diabetic patient should have the shortest starvation period possible – no more than one missed meal where possible.
Any concerns regarding diabetic control of the patient should be referred to the Anaesthetist and Consulting team in the first instance who must obtain advice from the Diabetic team.

All diabetic patients must be commenced on a diabetic monitoring chart on admission to the ward and have their blood sugars monitored hourly whilst fasting and in accordance with specific clinical guidance from the anaesthetist clearly documented in the health care records.

Blood sugars recorded at 12mmol/l or more in the immediate post-operative period should be reported to the patient's clinical consulting team who may wish to take further advice from the Consultant Anaesthetist.
For all diabetic paediatric surgical cases, please refer to the “Surgery and Anaesthesia – Safe Provision of Paediatric” Trust protocol for further advice.
All diabetic patients that continue to fast post-surgery for longer than  hours must be referred to the Diabetic Team.
Patient's for endoscopy
All patients for endoscopy will be provided with information regarding their fasting requirements in a timely manner prior to the procedure.
All patients will be provided with written and verbal instructions on bowel preparation for all procedures that require bowel preparation.
Following the endoscopic procedure the patient may be required to remain fasting for a short period and will be informed of this on completion of the procedure.
Admitted patients that are required to remain fasting post procedure for a period of time, will have this clearly documented in the health care records and the ward will be informed verbally.

The period of fasting required will be added to the nurse's handover sheet and all staff will be informed including housekeepers and ward hostess. Patients will be offered food and drink in accordance with the endoscopist's orders as soon as the period of fasting is completed to reduce the potential of the patient becoming dehydrated, unless clinically indicated due to nausea/vomiting or other complications of the procedure.

The nutrition and alert/risk board above the patient's bed will be updated with a black magnetic strip to indicate that the patient is fasting for a period of time only and the “Decision reminder aid will be added to the patient's folder at the end of the patient's bed following completion.
Nil by mouth protocol

Each patient who has a NBM order, must be assessed for alternative methods of hydration, nutrition and medication administration, unless it is an end of life decision (see also risk feeding in the oral nutrition policy).
All patients that are commenced on intravenous fluid replacement must have the input and output recorded on a fluid balance chart.

Staff must ensure patients who have a Nil by Mouth order will be physically and psychologically prepared for this period, as far as possibly by discussing the options, reasoning and proposed length of the NBM period for the patient.

Patients who do not have capacity and have undergone an MCA2 assessment, will have a NBM order issued in the patients best interest without either the patient's or families consent. However in this instance, the family will be informed of the reasoning behind the clinical decision made and kept updated.

The NBM plan must be clearly documented in the doctors and nursing records, handover sheet, NBM Protocol and Nutrition Alert and Risk Management above bed boards. A red strip must be placed on the board and all staff be aware that this denotes the patient being nil by mouth.
The NBM Protocol must be completed and added to the health care records.

Family members must be notified of any changes to the NBM order, in accordance with the patient's wishes who has capacity and consideration should be made for the patient and families wishes and concerns during the decision making process.
Patients will be treated with privacy and dignity at all times
The NBM Protocol must be completed and added to the health care records.
NBM orders should be reviewed every  hours by the clinician in charge of the patient and discussed with the patient and family members, if appropriate.

Whilst NBM, all oral medications should be reviewed on a daily basis as to alternative routes of administration or may be allowed orally and risk for medications that the patient was previously on. Patients particularly at risk are Diabetic and Parkinson patients and special attention should be given to reduce risk of deterioration in their medical condition.

Clear communication of the patient's status is recorded on the Nutrition Alert and Risk Management above bed boards and the plan is shared with the whole team including housekeeping staff throughout the patients NBM period.

All patients that are NBM should have mouth care every 2 hours, assessment for deterioration and actions taken to prevent soreness and dryness of the mouth leading to cracked tissues and oral infections developing. See Trust Mouth Care Policy.
All patients that are NBM must have their pressure ulcer risk assessment tool and body map to monitor for signs of deterioration in the patients skin integrity as per Trust Policy.

Nurses must consider other factors that may increase the risk of pressure sore development such as immobility and reduced nutrition when carrying out risk assessment of developing pressure sores and if at risk provide pressure re- distributing mattresses.
Breach reporting
A Datix web (DCIQ) should be completed for non-compliance with this guideline in the case of elective procedures.
In the case of emergency procedures the reasons for not waiting for full fasting should be clearly documented in the medical notes.
Training requirements
This policy is intended for use and should be read by all healthcare workers involved in the care of patients undergoing monitored anaesthesia care.
Monitoring and audit
Outlined below is the Trust's process of monitoring compliance with, and the effectiveness of the document's main points.
The use of these guidelines will be reviewed by yearly audits by the anaesthetic department

The standard for fasting times for non-emergency procedures is 100% of patients to have been offered a drink of clear fluid between 2-4 hours before anaesthesia. In the case of hand surgery where the planned anaesthetic technique is regional anaesthesia alone, patients should be allowed to drink clear fluids until they leave the ward for theatre.

All policies, procedures and guidelines will be approved by the Anaesthetic Assessment Group, which is the specialist group with the authority to approve local anaesthetic guidelines. These will then be forwarded to the Document control team for submission and ratification by the Joint Document Management Group.
It is the author's responsibility to inform the Anaesthetic Assessment Group of the approved policy documents when they are uploaded to the Trust's Intranets.

Appendix 1: Pre-operative fluid fasting guideline for children
This should be read in conjunction with Clinical Guideline 15020, Preoperative Fasting Policy for Adults and Children.
Policy
Policy for pre-operative fasting for children day case surgery and inpatient elective surgical admissions are:
6 hours for solid food.
4 hours for breast milk.
1 hour clear fluids.
(Clear fluids are defined as fluid through which print can be read. This is water, diluted squash or juice or ready diluted drinks such as Fruit Shoot or Ribena)

This is based on current evidence that 1 hour fasting for clear fluids does not lead to increased stomach volume, decreased pH or adverse outcome. (This policy is based on the GOSH pre-operative fasting policy for Woodpecker Ward implemented 2015).
Parental Information

Morning admissions: Parents will be advised at pre-assessment for morning admissions to give fluids up until 06.30 then stop. At 07.30 on admission a drink will be given to the child by nursing staff on arrival. This is to minimise unregulated large volumes of fluid intake prior to admission.
On Arrival to ward
A clear fluid drink will be provided on arrival at times above of 5ml/kg. If the weight of the child is not known an age dependent volume will be given to minimise delays.
Age 1-5 years- 60mls (White cup- bottom laminated line).
Age 6-11 years- 140mls (White cup- top laminated line).
Age  and above- A full white cup- 200mls.

data.text: Afternoon admission: Parents will be advised at pre-assessment for afternoon admissions to give fluids up until 11.30 then stop. Admission at 12.00. At 12 - 12.30 a drink will be given to the child by nursing staff. This is to minimise unregulated large volumes of fluid intake, prior to admission.

Following confirmation of list order further repeat drinks of similar volume to above can be given at hourly intervals to a cut off time following discussion with the anaesthetist looking after the child.
Exclusions
Children having emergency surgery (except urgent plastic and maxillofacial trauma – to be discussed with anaesthetist for list)
Children with delayed gastric emptying, GORD on treatment (ranitidine, domperidone, omeprazole ) or under investigation.
Children with other conditions that may affect gastric emptying, renal failure, enteropathies, oesophageal strictures, achalasia, diabetes mellitus.
Late comers should be excluded from the drink on arrival until list order and timing has been confirmed by the anaesthetist looking after the child.
Implementation and Regulation
This policy will be audited on implementation to ensure any negative impact on the service, such as delays, are noted or any complications occur.
References

Background evidence for new starvation times Excessive fasting can cause a great amount of distress for children and their carers. The AAGBI1 (Association of Anaesthetists Great Britain and Ireland) states that recommended fasting times are, six hours for food, four hours for breast milk, two hours for clear fluids.

The recent literature challenges the traditional fasting times. A recent study of 10,000 children, over a 6 year period, drinking free fluids up until the time of surgery does not increase their risk of aspiration2. This is supported by Schmidt et al3 , who showed there was no change in gastric pH or volume after 1 or 2 hours fasting. There is also ample evidence from radio-nucleotide studies that the time taken for more than 80% of clear fluid to exit the stomach is less than 1 hour4. Furthermore, if glucose is included in children's clear fluid then gastric emptying is significantly quicker5.
